    Guide to yang7er

Guide to yang7er

Source: vignettes/vignette.Rmd
vignette.Rmd

Description

yang7er provides the calculation of the difference between state and regional hpi, as well as graphing the change in state hpi, and the change in regional hpi.

A house price index (HPI) measures the price changes of residential housing as a percentage change from some specific start date (which has an HPI of 100). The built-in data in this package comes from Federal Housing Finance Agency, it included the HPI in US by states from 1975 to 2018.

This vignette shows you how to derive the HPI difference between a state and its region, an image of the state’s HPI change, and an image of the region’s change using the yang7er package

Load the yang7er package using the library() function.

library(yang7er)

Built-in data description

HPI Data Description
Variable Type Description
year double year
month double month
state character states in US
price_index double house price index
us_avg double us annual average HPI
year_avg double every stats’s anaual average HPI
us_year_avg double us annual average HPI
region character state belongs in which region
region_avg double every region’s anaual average HPI

The HPI data sets needed for this blog comes from the Federal Housing Finance Agency, which is a tabular data with 26877 rows and 9 columns of data. More details about this dataset can be found by using the function help(hpi)

Example of the Package

1.get_hpi

If you want to check the build-in data, you can use:

get_hpi()
#> Rows: 26877 Columns: 5
#> ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> Delimiter: ","
#> chr (1): state
#> dbl (4): year, month, price_index, us_avg
#> 
#> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
#> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
#> Joining, by = "state"
#> # A tibble: 26,877 × 9
#> # Groups:   year, region [220]
#>     year month state price_index us_avg year_avg us_year_avg region      regio…¹
#>    <dbl> <dbl> <chr>       <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl>       <dbl> <chr>         <dbl>
#>  1  1975     1 AK           34.6   23.5     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#>  2  1975     2 AK           35.1   23.6     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#>  3  1975     3 AK           35.5   23.8     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#>  4  1975     4 AK           35.9   24.1     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#>  5  1975     5 AK           36.3   24.2     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#>  6  1975     6 AK           36.7   24.2     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#>  7  1975     7 AK           37.2   24.3     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#>  8  1975     8 AK           37.7   24.4     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#>  9  1975     9 AK           38.4   24.5     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#> 10  1975    10 AK           39.1   24.6     37.2        24.2 Pacific We…    26.4
#> # … with 26,867 more rows, and abbreviated variable name ¹​region_avg

2.diff_region_state

If you want to get the information of Ak, in 2006, you can use:

diff_region_state("AK",2016)
#> # A tibble: 1 × 6
#> # Groups:   state, year [1]
#>    year state region            region_avg state_avg  diff
#>   <dbl> <chr> <chr>                  <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1  2016 AK    Pacific West Area       184.      174.  9.83

3.diff_plot

If you want to plot the AK's hpi change, and compare with its region’s change, you can use:

diff_plot("AK")

The change of HPI in Ak, Pacific West Area

4.regions_plot

If you want to plot regions’ hpi change from 1990 to 2018, you can use:

regions_plot(1990,2018)

The change of HPI in all regions from 1990 to 2018
